metadata.dc:description: Eccrine pore carcinoma is an infrequent malign skin tumour that derives from the eccrine sweat glands, it fundamentally affects persons of advanced age, its growth is slow and it is predominantly located in the lower extremities. Its high malignancy and its potentiality for giving rise to distant metastasis makes it necessary to carry out aggressive surgical treatments with lymphadenectomies of the ganglion chains. There are no more than 300 tumours of this type described in the literature. Our study examines 9 cases detected in Navarra in the last ten years and analyses its clinical and histopathological behaviour. The chosen surgical treatment was extirpation with safety margins of 2 cm; we did not carry out prophylactic lymphadenectomies. At present the survival rate of patients is 100% and only in one of the series has a lymphatic metastasis been detected.
